text: We sit here together on low, sturdy, moogany deck chairs, taking inventory of the scene. There's a silence doorwater of the illuminated swimming pool. It's our new rental.

Well, be here for eight weeks, and this is the first tire. We take deep breaths without speaking any words. After three bombing days of driving, we both feel the remains of a recent adrenaline spike after all. We finally arrived. But exhaustion will win out shortly, and if we don't fall asleep here in this recline, well pull out ourselves together and drift away into separate beds.

There will be time for our effortless backstrokes in this pool now before us. And if we feel like it, maybe we will explore the contours of what seems to be a well-mancured backyard. Or maybe not. At our current precise moment I feel I may never leave this chair. Ever. Like literally. I might die here. Or laugh forever. This is a numbness to this tired mind and body.

We wonder a while and settle into a rhythm of inandic sales, just rising and lowings slowly in gently.

We talked a lot on the road and this moment feels like a trophy. We watch a leaf become detached from one of the overhead trees. It falls with a graceful leisure and then, to our muted surprise, stopped mid air some four feet above the surface of the glowing pool. The dry brown leaf wobbles a bit then start spinning slowly.

We remain unchanged in our outward emotionless, just does steadily rising and falling. Internally, we land on the same thought, this must be some sort of miniature whirlwind otherwise invisible, unfailing to produce the slightest effect on the surface water of the pool or anywhere else. But then, it becomes evident that instead this is actually one of those small miracles. We watch for a while before deciding it's time to sleep. The following morning, the leaf was still floating in place, though now complete emotionless.

Further inspection revealed a thread of spider silk, a miracle of a different thought. We ease into the chilly pool. Between us we know it's going to be a scorcher today. Over a hundred for the seventh day in a row. Army presence in the pool brings the floating leaf to a slow curved sway, ranking it amongst the most elegant pendulums in all of existence anywhere for the moment, anyway, or maybe ever.
